stages.title: Reactive Survival
stages.description: Pure existence without self-reflection. You're all sensation and reaction - hungry, tired, comfortable, uncomfortable. No separation between you and experience.
stages.quote: Have you ever watched an infant discovering their hands? That look of 'Holy shit, these are mine?!' That's where we all started...
stages.examples: Infants, people in states of extreme survival emergency, moments of pure flow state
stages.pathways: Certain meditation practices that focus on pure sensory experience; moments of complete absorption in physical activity

stages.title: Personal Self
stages.description: Discovering yourself as separate from the world. You have wants, needs, and feelings that are uniquely yours. The world revolves around you.
stages.quote: Kids are the only honest people left on the planet. 'I want that toy!' No social niceties, no 'Well, actually, I was thinking that perhaps if it wouldn't be too much trouble...' Just pure, unfiltered desire.
stages.examples: Young children, moments of unapologetic self-interest in adults, people focused solely on personal desires
stages.pathways: Focused self-exploration therapy; practices that reconnect you with authentic desires

stages.title: Social Self
stages.description: Discovering that others' opinions matter. Your identity is defined by relationships and social expectations. You internalize the rules and values of your tribe.
stages.quote: Go back to bed, America. Your government has figured out how the world works... Here's American Gladiators. Watch this, shut up, go back to bed America, here is American Gladiators, here is 56 channels of it!
stages.examples: Most adults, corporate employees, those who primarily identify with their social roles or groups
stages.pathways: Immersion in new cultural environments; intentional exposure to diverse perspectives; some group psychedelic experiences

stages.title: Rational Agency
stages.description: Developing independent thought. You question social norms, evaluate evidence critically, and form your own conclusions. Things are true or false regardless of what others believe.
stages.quote: Think for yourself, question authority. Throughout human history, as our species has faced the frightening, terrorizing fact that we do not know who we are, or where we are going in this ocean of chaos...
stages.examples: Scientists, independent thinkers, philosophers, social critics
stages.pathways: Rigorous study of critical thinking; debate; practices that challenge assumptions

stages.title: Self Authoring
stages.description: Recognizing that you create your reality. You understand how your needs shape your feelings, how your preferences shape your identity, and you take responsibility for who you are.
stages.quote: The world is like a ride at an amusement park, and when you choose to go on it, you think it's real, because that's how powerful our minds are... But it doesn't matter because it's just a ride, and we can change it anytime we want.
stages.examples: Wise teachers, integrated leaders, masterful therapists, mature artists
stages.pathways: Deep shadow work; authentic relating practices; conscious relationship to archetypes

stages.title: Enlightened Mind
stages.description: Direct perception of the constructed nature of reality. You see how the mind creates qualia and experience. The boundary between self and mind begins to dissolve.
stages.quote: Today, a young man on acid realized that all matter is merely energy condensed to a slow vibration â€“ that we are all one consciousness experiencing itself subjectively. There's no such thing as death, life is only a dream...
stages.examples: Advanced meditators, mystics, those who've had profound non-dual experiences
stages.pathways: Deep meditation practices; structured psychedelic experiences with integration (DMT, ayahuasca); certain breathwork techniques

stages.title: Transcendent Mind
stages.description: Beyond conventional consciousness. The self as traditionally understood dissolves, opening possibilities for radically different forms of awareness and being.
stages.examples: Perhaps not fully achievable in conventional human form; glimpses in profound mystical states
stages.pathways: Joscha Bach speculates this might be more relevant to the future evolution of consciousness, possibly through AGI integration

questions.question: When faced with a challenging situation, what is your first instinct?
questions.description: Think about your immediate response, not what you do after reflection.

options.text: React emotionally based on how it makes me feel
Consider how others would expect me to respond
Analyze the problem logically to find the best solution
Consider multiple perspectives and potential outcomes
Notice my thoughts arising but don't immediately identify with them

questions.question: Which statement best describes your view of personal identity?
questions.description: What feels most true about who you are at your core?

options.text: I am my needs, desires, and emotions
I am my relationships and roles in society
I am my values, beliefs, and rational mind
I create my identity through conscious choices
Identity is fluid and constructed by the mind
Identity is an illusion; consciousness exists prior to self

questions.question: When someone disagrees with an opinion you hold strongly, you typically:
questions.description: Think about your most natural response in conversations.

options.text: Feel personally attacked and get defensive
Worry about maintaining harmony in the relationship
Try to convince them with facts and logical arguments
Get curious about their perspective and why we see things differently
See both views as partial truths within a larger context
Observe the arising of opinions without attachment to either view

questions.question: Which best describes your relationship with societal rules and norms?
questions.description: How do you generally view cultural expectations?

options.text: I follow them to avoid punishment or rejection
I value them as important for social cohesion
I evaluate them based on logic and principles
I create my own value system that may or may not align with society
I see them as constructs that can be useful but aren't inherently true
I move fluidly between different frameworks as appropriate

questions.question: When making an important life decision, what factors weigh most heavily?
questions.description: What ultimately drives your biggest choices?

options.text: What I want and what makes me happy
What others would think or expect of me
What makes the most logical sense based on evidence
What aligns with my personal values and vision
What serves the greater whole and multiple perspectives
The choice emerges naturally when I'm not identified with the decider

questions.question: How do you typically experience difficult emotions?
questions.description: When you feel anger, fear, or sadness, what's your relationship with those feelings?

options.text: I am those emotions; they overtake me completely
I try to control them to maintain social relationships
I analyze them to understand what caused them
I see them as information about my values and needs
I observe them as passing phenomena in awareness
I experience them fully while recognizing they're not who I am

questions.question: Which statement best reflects your view on contradictions and paradoxes?
questions.description: How do you handle seemingly opposing truths?

options.text: They're confusing and frustrating
One side must be right and the other wrong
They can be resolved with enough logical analysis
They're interesting and can hold partial truths
They're natural and reveal the limits of conceptual thinking
They dissolve when viewed from awareness beyond concepts

questions.question: How would you describe your sense of connection to others?
questions.description: What feels most true about your relationship with other people?

options.text: Others are primarily there to meet my needs
Connection comes through conforming to social expectations
I connect with those who share my values and goals
I can connect deeply while maintaining my boundaries
We're all interconnected parts of a larger whole
Separation is an illusion; consciousness is shared

questions.question: When you encounter something new that challenges your beliefs, you tend to:
questions.description: How do you approach intellectual or spiritual challenges?

options.text: Reject it if it doesn't fit with what I already believe
Analyze it logically to see if it makes sense
Integrate useful aspects into my evolving worldview
Appreciate how it expands my understanding
Recognize all beliefs as mental constructs

questions.question: Which statement best captures your experience of consciousness?
questions.description: What feels most true about your moment-to-moment experience?

options.text: I experience life through my personal desires and emotions
My identity is shaped by my social roles and relationships
I am a rational agent making decisions based on evidence
I actively create meaning and author my own story
I witness my thoughts and experiences arising in awareness
I am the boundless awareness in which all experience appears
